senses.de: The money a person needs to pay to travel by taxi, bus, train, etc.
senses.ex: The bus fare from New York to Boston is $35.

Tips.title: Transportation Cost
Tips.description: Refers to the price for public or private vehicle travel.
Tips.example: Could you tell me the taxi fare to the airport?

Tips.title: Additional Fees
Tips.description: Fare might not include extras like tolls or tips.
Tips.example: The fare is $25, but that doesn't cover the bridge toll.

Tips.title: Fixed or Variable
Tips.description: Some fares are fixed prices, others increase with distance or time.
Tips.example: Is the bus fare to downtown a fixed rate?

senses.de: To perform in a specified way in a specific situation.
senses.ex: How did your team fare in the match today?

Tips.title: Assessing Performance
Tips.description: Used to comment on someone's or something's success or failure.
Tips.example: Without a strong strategy, our team didn't fare too well.

Tips.title: Subjectivity
Tips.description: How well someone fares can be subjective, depending on expectations.
Tips.example: She fared better than expected in her new role.

senses.ex: The restaurant serves traditional Italian fare.

Tips.title: Culinary Offerings
Tips.description: Concerns the variety or style of food provided.
Tips.example: The street festival had an array of local fare.

Tips.title: Cultural Association
Tips.description: Fare often implies traditional or characteristic food of a region.
Tips.example: You must try our regional fare, especially the cheese.

senses.de: To experience something, usually something negative.
senses.ex: Many small businesses fared poorly during the recession.

Tips.title: Enduring Difficulty
Tips.description: Indicates how well one handles adverse conditions or events.
Tips.example: How did the crops fare after the heavy rains?

Tips.title: Phrasal Context
Tips.description: Commonly used in questions or statements about well-being.
Tips.example: After the long journey, the travelers fared quite poorly.

Charge.wordDefinition:
Charge refers to the price that someone has to pay for a product or service, whereas fare is specifically used to describe the price that someone pays for transportation services such as a bus, train, or taxi.

For example, a restaurant might charge you for the food you order or a plumber might charge you for fixing a leaky faucet.

Cost.wordDefinition:
Cost usually refers to the amount of money spent on a product or service to produce, purchase, or operate it. Fare typically refers to the amount paid for a journey, such as a bus or train journey, or for transport services like cab or taxi.

For example, the cost of a T-shirt may include the fabric, thread, labor, and other expenses needed to produce it. The fare for a train ride may depend on the distance traveled and the class of the compartment booked.

Cost usually refers to the total amount spent on something, while fare generally refers to the amount paid for a specific travel journey.

Expense.wordDefinition:
Expense refers to the amount of money spent on something, like a purchase or a bill, usually for something that is not a journey or trip.

For example: "The expense of buying a new car was more than I thought it would be."

To summarize, expense is used when talking about the amount of money spent on purchases or bills, while fare is used when talking about the price of transportation.

Fee.wordDefinition:
Fee generally refers to the amount of money you pay to use a service, like the fee paid to a doctor's office for a medical check-up or to a university for the tuition fee.

A fare is what you pay to get from one place to another using public transportation like buses, trains, taxis or planes while a fee is what you pay for a service or use of a facility such as taking a course or using a gym or library.

Price.wordDefinition:
Fare refers specifically to the cost of transportation, such as the fare for a bus, train, or airplane ticket. Price, on the other hand, refers to the cost of a product or service in general.

This could include anything from the price of a new pair of shoes to the price of a meal at a restaurant. Fare is applicable when discussing transportation costs, while price is applicable when discussing the cost of any product or service.

Rate.wordDefinition:
Rate is a broader term that refers to the cost of something per unit or over a period of time, such as the exchange rate between two currencies or the interest rate on a loan.

Fare is more specific to transportation costs while rate is more general and versatile in its application.

Tariff.wordDefinition:
Fare and tariff are two words used to describe the amount of money people have to pay for transportation.

Tariff describes the amount of money charged for transportation of goods or cargo. Tariff is used specifically for shipping, trade, or commerce.

It is a tax or duty that is levied by a government on goods that are imported or exported. For example, when goods are imported or exported between countries, tariffs are added to the cost of the shipment as a way to protect domestic industries or to raise revenue for the government.

Fare is the amount of money a person pays for public transportation, while tariff is the amount of money charged for transporting goods or cargo.

Toll.wordDefinition:
Both fare and toll are words that refer to a fee or charge for using a mode of transportation or road, but they are used in different contexts.

Toll is a fee paid for using certain roads or bridges. Toll roads are often more expensive than regular roads because they are designed to generate revenue to pay for their construction and maintenance.

For example, if you drive over a bridge, you may have to pay a toll to cross it.

Fare is used when referring to public transportation and toll is used when referring to a fee for using a road or bridge.

quotes.Text: Films don't always tell a story; some films can achieve effect just by being razzle-dazzle or rock n' roll. That's part of the fare that's out there. And that's okay. For me, I place more value on a story.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Robert Redford

quotes.Text: I tend toward more adult fare, and I would love to do a voice in an animated film or something the boys could go see, but at a certain point, I made peace with myself about it.

quotes.Text: I wanted the young African-American girls also on the bus to know that they had a right to be there, because they had paid their fare just like the white passengers.

quotes.Text: Consumers fare best when the barriers to business entry are low, which helps ensure that the market - any market - becomes competitive and stays that way.

quotes.Text: As far as the type of movies I am offered is concerned, it's a mix. I have been offered both period films and the regular fare.

quotes.Text: Whoever understands how to do a kindness when he fares well would be a friend better than any possession.

quotes.Text: It's not what color you are or how you fare with fans, it's who you are and what personality you have.

quotes.Text: Death is easier than a wretched life; and better never to have born than to live and fare badly.

quotes.Name: Aeschylus

quotes.Text: I'm interested in how innocence fares when it collides with hard reality.

quotes.Text: I don't believe in awards, and I think only film fare awards are faring.
